China must keep to rules, EU warns, amid fears it wants to become dominant economic powerEU's Van Rompuy says China "must be open and transparent" in managing its currencyEU must decide whether to label Chinese exports as "subsidized"The EU should "take action" if the People's Bank of China does not keep to the rules governing the value of its currency, says the EU president, Herman Van Rompuy. He also said it was time to decide whether Chinese exports should be labeled as "subsidized," as European companies say the Chinese state is helping its companies export by keeping the renminbi low."We are determined to fight against competitive devaluation," Van Rompuy said on the sidelines of a speech in Berlin. "If the Chinese government keeps to the rules, we are prepared to work with them. But if they don't, we must take action."The Chinese currency is currently trading against the euro at a rate of just over 1.28 euros. Last year, the rate briefly dropped below 1.21 euros, which made Chinese exports appear to be far cheaper than those from other countries.'Significant' dropThe German economy has been weakened by a decline in exports to ChinaGerman Economy Minister Philipp Rösler echoed Van Rompuy's stance on Wednesday, telling Die Zeit newspaper that "we must take a firm stance against competitive devaluation in China, and we must not allow China to export at a lower price than its Western competitors."Rösler said if Chinese exporters are "getting support from the Chinese government that's not in line with market forces and the spirit of the World Trade Organization, then China's export goods should be considered as subsidized in the EU, and that must be clearly said in customs tariffs."Ahead of Van Rompuy's comments, EU Trade Commissioner Karel De Gucht had told Reuters news agency that he would not be surprised if the EU Commission branded exports from China as "subsidized," which would mean higher EU tariffs on Chinese goods."

网综合检视巴西·“透明科技计划”检视2010选举(2010 Global Trends Report)China's future direction: a review of the 2010 Global Trends ReportThe 2010 Global Trends Report (GT Report, hereafter) published by the US National Intelligence Council (NIC) on September 27, 2010, analyzes China's future direction, as a part of its overall vision of trends in the world in 2010. The GT Report says that China will “…become a normal great power, exercising its power in a restrained and sustainable manner” and “…continue to move up the global power hierarchy.” It also notes that China will become the world's largest economy in 2012. The GT Report, the latest version of the NIC's Global Trends 2025 (Global Trends 2025 Report, hereafter) published in 2005 and updated in 2009, is an authoritative source for foreign governments and international institutions to study China’s future development. It has drawn much attention from scholars and media outlets for its analytical content, and for its authoritative voice. The Chinese government has also reacted to its contents in an open and positive way.The GT Report is of importance to the outside world mainly because it is not only the latest report on China, but also because it is the most authoritative report, which not only comprehensively reviews China’s future development but also integrates the analyses of other global trends. We present the following analyses of the report.Analytical content and methodology of the GT ReportThe GT Report reviews China’s future development in 2010-2030 under the overall framework of the four trends: the “globalization of political power,” the “globalization of governance,” the “digitalization of all things” and the “collapse of traditional economic power.”Political power has become more diverse, plural and multipolar. There are new major political players: the USA, China and India. The center of political power is shifting to Asia.

“The Freedom Park” is a documentary by Chinese filmmaker Zhang Lu. It is based on the story of Chinese people trying to fight back after authorities confiscated their land for a development project.The land in the small rural village of Baimajing in China’s Sichuan province was once a center for farmers. It was the site of one of the earliest land grabs in the region.By the end of the year 2000, the land was sold for the construction of the Three Gorges Dam. The project displaced more than one million people. Many of them lost their land and their livelihoods.In Baimajing, farmers were forced to give up their land, despite the fact that they had cultivated the fields for decades. As a result, their villages began to die out, and many farmers emigrated in search for work.A few determined farmers decided to take action. They started to stage sit-ins in the local park. In order to raise awareness about their cause, they filmed a video about their struggle. The video, entitled “The Freedom Park,” gained some popularity on the internet, and eventually led to them gaining more support.According to official figures, more than 250,000 Chinese citizens are staging demonstrations in parks and squares in protest of local land seizures. Some of them are even calling themselves “naked protesters.”Despite China’s increasingly strict censorship regime, the video went viral on WeChat, the country’s most popular messaging platform.While some were moved by the story, others questioned whether the movie was made with the approval of local authorities, and accused the filmmakers of “stirring up unrest” in the region.This is not the first time Zhang Lu has been critical of the Chinese government’s policies. Since 2008, the film director has produced eight documentaries, which were all about real life events in China.His most controversial documentary “The Flowers of War” (2008) deals with the World War II-era Japanese occupation of Nanjing.

On Sunday, China will host the first National Security Education Day, a Chinese-initiated educational campaign with the aim of “enhancing the capacity of each individual to contribute to China's National Security”. The campaign, which is set to take place annually on the first Sunday of every August, has attracted significant interest from government and public media outlets across the country.China's National Security Education Day is part of the new Chinese Education Law, and is meant to be accompanied by an extensive set of guidelines on how to organize and promote various education campaigns. The campaign has sparked controversy online, and here are five of the most popular discussions on Chinese social media:What is National Security Education?A campaign for the education and improvement of national security is not novel; a related initiative called “Jiao Ke Bao,” or National Defense Training, was initiated in 1999 by the Central Military Commission (CMC). It was intended to educate every “party member, cadre and civilian” and “promote an educated and civilized public opinion that is able to respond properly to all forms of risks and dangers” — essentially ensuring that everyone understood the “spirit of the Party and country”. The project came to a halt in 2013.However, the current “National Security Education” campaign takes a more direct approach. According to one of the campaign guidelines, the goal of the education program is to “enhance the capacity of each individual to contribute to China's National Security” through four specific objectives: “national unity, national stability, the healthy and beautiful society, and to enhance national power, international influence, and to achieve the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation.” The guidelines explicitly stated that the campaign was targeted at “every person of the whole society, including young people, college students, women and the elderly.”

是复习的错误by 钱樓“If the Chinese economy is not a part of the global economy, it would be like putting a bullet in one’s head,” wrote Li Huiyong, a professor at the College of Foreign Languages at the Central University for Nationalities in Beijing. “Economic globalization is like a huge river that cannot be stopped. It is more suitable to walk into it.”China, Li told the Washington Post, has embraced free trade because it wants to become part of the global system that has served it so well. The country doesn’t want to be left out of the new, open economy. “We hope to get involved in its flow,” he said, “so we can use its strong tides to lift the boat of Chinese people.”When Beijing speaks of embracing globalization, many of us hear “China wants to be part of the global economy.”But what exactly does “globalization” mean today? How are we defining it? Globalization is the process by which economic actors across national and cultural boundaries are coming together to reshape the world economy.The world as we see it today is a result of decades of cross-border trading and the development of international institutions. These activities have changed the geography, economic structure and political culture of the world.The rise of China has not simply been a result of the growth of its domestic economy but also of the integration into the global economy over the past three decades.With an economy that is nearly five times the size of Japan and with more foreign trade than that of the United States, China is indeed playing a major role in shaping the emerging global economy.By joining the global economy, China has not merely benefited itself, but has also brought about a better life for hundreds of millions of its citizens.In 1979, Deng Xiaoping’s famous speech at the “Four Modernizations” conference outlined the main goals for Chinese economic reform: to open up to the world, to become a socialist market economy, to make the country great and to improve people’s welfare.

(Law)法律窗口双重危境Double Jeopardy (Law)法律窗口：双重危境Double Jeopardy (Law)I. The Double JeopardyAs we all know, the principle of double jeopardy prevents one from being tried twice for the same crime. For example, two persons are accused of committing theft, and the court finds that both of them actually committed theft. But neither of them is convicted, because under the principle of double jeopardy they cannot be tried again. Similarly, two persons commit theft, one is convicted, the other is not convicted, and both of them cannot be tried again for the same crime.The principle of double jeopardy is closely related to the principle of double punishment. The principle of double punishment can be illustrated by a case. Person A is accused of committing theft. As a result of the investigation, A is convicted of the crime of theft. He is sentenced to two years’ imprisonment, and he appeals from his sentence. The appeal is heard, and on the basis of new evidence that was not available at the time A was convicted, the Supreme Court acquits A. Consequently, there is no longer any proof that A committed the crime of theft, and therefore A cannot be retried for the same crime. In the case of A, however, if B, who also committed theft, is convicted of the crime, there is nothing to prevent A from being tried again for the crime of theft. That is why the principle of double punishment applies only to crimes for which A cannot be punished.II. The Definition of a CrimeFor the purpose of applying the principle of double punishment, it is necessary to define a crime. According to Chinese Criminal Law, a crime is defined as “any behavior that results in violation of the law by injuring, deceiving, or cheating other people.”[1] This definition covers many different kinds of behavior, including theft, rape, homicide, bribery, drug trafficking, and kidnapping.However, from a legal point of view, it is not necessary for a person to commit the crime in order to be punished for committing that crime.

On the morning of Oct. 1, 2004, thousands of Americans, many dressed in red, white and blue, lined up at airports across the United States to welcome home U.S. troops from the war in Iraq.But at one of the largest airports in the nation, that welcome was dampened by the sight of a handful of protesters who opposed the war and U.S. President George W. Bush.A group of about 75 protesters, organized by the anti-war group Code Pink, held up anti-war signs with messages like "Support Our Troops" and "Bring the Troops Home Now."One protester at Philadelphia International Airport, Ellen Dannin of Philadelphia, wore a sign that read "Veterans Against War."She said that in previous wars, American veterans had not been treated well by the U.S. government."We can't let history repeat itself," she said. "We can't repeat the same mistakes from the past."The protesters were at the airport to welcome home members of the 82nd Airborne Division who were coming home from Iraq.The demonstration ended with the arrest of a protester accused of spitting at a U.S. Marine. Police were called in after he shouted at an American flag at the foot of an Army transport bus.There were no major incidents. The demonstration, and the protesters, were outnumbered by supporters, including a small plane flying over the scene with a banner that read "Welcome Home 82nd."It was the first of a series of planned protests that took place at airports throughout the country as U.S. troops were returning home from Iraq.

The man is said to have used the fake bomb threat as a ploy to get through airport security and board a plane for Iran.A court in Hamburg has sent a 49-year-old Iranian citizen who made a fake bomb threat at Hamburg Airport to jail for one year and six months. Prosecutors say the man was trying to flee the country.The court said the defendant had told officials he was carrying a bomb and he would detonate it if they did not let him onto his flight to Tehran. However, the police searched the area and found no explosives. After further investigation it was discovered that the man has a history of making fake bomb threats in order to get past security checkpoints.The court also ruled that the man must stay in Hamburg, which he apparently never intended to do, as he is not allowed to leave Germany while he is being tried. The Iranian man was identified only by his last name, Ebrahimi.

:分散的对话China is a country that has made tremendous strides in its economic development and opening-up. This was made possible by decades of reform and opening-up, with pragmatic policies and a clear strategic direction. Over the past few years, China’s success has become increasingly impressive. It has become the world's second-largest economy with the largest population, and has been ranked among the world’s top three major economies for the first time.China’s GDP growth was 6.9 percent last year. China’s industrial value-added and per capita disposable income both rose to their highest levels in history. China’s development has greatly improved people’s living conditions. Life expectancy has reached 77.4 years. The number of poor people has dropped significantly from 770 million in 1981 to 23 million last year. The drop was unprecedented in the annals of human history. And the poverty rate in rural areas has fallen from 99.9 percent in 1966 to 0.7 percent last year.All these achievements were made as China steadily pursued the socialist path with Chinese characteristics. This year marks the 70th anniversary of the victory of the Chinese People’s War of Resistance Against Japanese Aggression and the Victory of the Chinese People’s Revolution. This event, as well as the 30th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration on the Establishment of the People’s Republic of China, falls in a special year when the CCP Central Committee and the State Council, China’s top political organ, are stepping up their efforts to comprehensively deepen reform and opening-up.China has achieved its economic development because the people have a strong sense of mission and a strong desire for a better life. It also realized rapid growth thanks to the CCP’s leadership and the unified leadership of the Chinese government. In particular, the strong centralized and unified leadership of the Party is the greatest strength of the CPC.To realize the dream of the Chinese people for a better life, China needs to maintain its strategic decision-making on reforms and opening-up. As President Xi Jinping said in his keynote speech at the recent Second Boao Forum for Asia Annual Conference, China has to adhere to its commitment to reform and opening-up and improve its opening-up measures.

I was surprised to discover that many Buddhists and Christians in China pray to the same “Tianzun,” or Lord of Heaven. But it turns out that Lord of Heaven in Chinese is simply the name for the Buddha. The name is also used to refer to Christ or to any other “supreme being,” so that a statue of Buddha in front of a church has the same status as a statue of Christ. “Tianzun” was a Buddhist deity until the end of the fifth century.This confusion is not limited to China. Even in the West, many people confuse “Tianzun” with “Tian Wang,” the Chinese name for the Buddha. These two words sound similar and mean the same thing.The mistake is understandable, however. The two men had many things in common, although not necessarily in their personal attributes. Both were born as princes, both died by crucifixion and were both resurrected. In some places, they were even buried in the same grave.There is also a similarity in the stories of their births. Both were born at midnight as the result of divine births. In the case of Buddha, he was conceived by the goddess of the night, who sent him down as a seed through a golden vessel. Jesus was conceived in a manger after his mother Mary gave birth in a stable.

跳踏涟涣阔滨"China's South China Sea claim rejected in the Hague"In a case that has set nerves on edge across Asia, the Permanent Court of Arbitration in the Netherlands ruled against China in a case brought by the Philippines, saying there was no legal basis for Beijing to claim historic rights to resources across swathes of the South China Sea.China has reacted angrily to the court's decision, rejecting its validity and vowing to disregard the ruling.The court rejected China's nine-dash line claim to 90 percent of the South China Sea, saying it was incompatible with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS).The court also ruled that a 200-nautical mile economic exclusion zone around reefs claimed by China, the Philippines and Vietnam was unlawful, but that Philippines' exclusive economic zone (EEZ) was unlawful as it overlapped with Vietnam's EEZ in an area south of Thitu Island.

On September 15, 2014, the “Tribute to the Memory of the Great Liberation” event was held in China’s Hong Kong to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the liberation of the Chinese mainland, marking the day that the nation-building work of the CPC reached a crucial juncture, the first time that the event was held outside the Chinese mainland. More than 100 Chinese and foreign guests attended the ceremony, among whom were Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying, Chinese Vice Premier Wang Yang, Guangdong governor Ma Xingrui, Chinese vice minister of foreign affairs Fu Ying, Hong Kong Secretary for Security Lai Tung-kwok, and Beijing’s representatives in Hong Kong.Chairman Mao Zedong and the First Lady were the guests of honor at the gathering, while Lin Biao was the honored guest. It was reported that the Chinese representatives delivered messages of congratulations from President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang and an invitation to the Great Hall of the People in Beijing to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People’s Republic of China in 2017.Addressing the gathering, Hong Kong’s chief executive Leung Chun-ying expressed congratulations and best wishes to the Chinese mainland on the occasion, saying that the people of Hong Kong are determined to join the Chinese mainland in the country’s march forward. He reiterated Hong Kong’s unwavering support for the one country, two systems formula, and the city’s long-standing “one country, two systems” principle which has been repeatedly affirmed.

The recent wave of protests in Hong Kong have shone a spotlight on the controversial Chinese policy of "re-education". Chinese officials have been speaking out to defend it. "If you have a criminal record you won't be able to board a plane or get a loan from the bank. In this context, re-education doesn't mean a vacation," said Qin Feng, Director of the School of Marxism at Renmin University in Beijing. "If you are going to work or study abroad, you have to correct your thinking," Mr Qin told BBC News. "The law has the same punishment for Chinese people and foreigners. Why should they get a different treatment?" On Chinese social media, thousands of comments have expressed support for China's position. One user, 'Wu Zuohua', said on Sina Weibo: "I don't understand the concept of're-education'. I believe it is in the process of abolishing". However, there have also been criticisms from Chinese netizens who claim they have been victims of "re-education" themselves. They say it infringes on their basic rights and is a waste of money. In China, this compulsory'reeducation' is provided by the authorities and some see it as a way to silence political opposition. The government has been running a national campaign to clean up the Internet, with a particular emphasis on so-called "illegal preaching". For example, on social media platforms like Weibo, netizens can be called upon by their local police departments if they are suspected of illegal activity. Some argue that this has led to a general fear of expressing opinions online.The recent wave of protests in Hong Kong have shone a spotlight on the controversial Chinese policy of “re-education”. The Great Leap Forward (simplified Chinese: 大积技水; traditional Chinese: 大坤技水; pinyin: Dàfǔjìn Wǔdǒng; Hanyu pinyin: Dàfǔjiǔn Wǔdǒng) was a campaign implemented between 1957 and 1961 by the ruling Communist Party of China (CPC) to rapidly build new factories and communes throughout the country. The goal was to transform the country's largely agrarian, feudal economy to an industrialised one. Its implementation ended in a severe famine that killed millions of people.The Great Leap Forward was an example of mass movement. It relied heavily on mobilization, including mass mobilization of rural labour. It was the culmination of other efforts to modernize China by encouraging the growth of cities. The Great Leap Forward encouraged urbanization at the expense of the countryside by providing incentives for farmers to abandon their crops and join urban construction projects, most of which did not produce useful commodities.Contents [hide]1 History2 The campaign3 Mass movements and their dangers4 Aftermath5 References6 External links7 External linksHistory[edit]Chairman Mao Zedong initiated the Great Leap Forward with an address given at the Ninth Plenary Session of the Eighth Central Committee on 8 October 1956. The campaign was to be based on the teachings of Mao Zedong's little red book which advocated "revolutionary" actions such as mass mobilization and revolution in production methods.[1] The campaign was launched on 25 October 1958, in Nanchang, Jiangxi, with a speech by Mao Zedong.[2][3] According to Deng Xiaoping's memoir, Mao stated at this time, "All my life I have been dreaming of the possibility that this generation might see China become a socialist country. I have no other wish, so I have no other thought."[

*什么是双重危境* 美国宪法第五条修正案指出，任何人不得因同一罪行而两次遭受生命或身体的危害，也就是说不能因同一犯罪而受到两次审判，这就是人们常说的“双重危境条款”。双重危境原则植根于西方的法律制度，并且一直可以追溯到圣经的旧约世代，希伯来法律中有类似双重处罚的规定，到了希腊和罗马时代早期，双重危境原则开始形成，后来又成为英国普通法的一部份，并运用到英国在北美的殖民地。美国开国先贤在制定联邦宪法修正案时加入了有关条款。洛杉矶洛约拉法学院教授塞谬尔·皮尔斯伯里介绍了双重危境条款包括的内容：“如果审判以被告无罪释放告终，双重危境就很容易避免，因为不会出现进一步的诉讼，也不能对判决提出上诉。

在北海石油平台周围，已经有 5 个新的勘察钻井在运作。但是 RWE Dea 公司也积极地在陆地上寻找更多的油层。比如在下萨克森的吉弗恩以北大约150平方公里的范围以及在石勒苏益格 - 荷尔施泰因州普伦地区约400平方公里的大范围区域。类似这样的钻探不仅很昂贵，而且前景未卜。在德国这样的勘探成功率仅为40% 。仅仅钻井可能就要耗费近3000万欧元。此外还通常要为地震勘测耗费上千万欧元的资金。可以预料的是，原油的价格很快又会涨价到每吨600欧元以上。因此RWE Dea公司和其他能源公司在本国探寻原油时，都不会为高额的前期投入所吓倒。德里克·默舍尔总结说，尽管投资高昂，但从中期来看，这不会是一笔亏本的生意：“从这一点来看，我们可以做到效益经营。 ”由于有了新的开采技术，人们也需要考虑对现有的石油储备作重新估计。

中国作为经济大国的崛起已经举世公认，而对于世界头号经济强国美国来说，如何维持和发展美中经贸关系，却是一个巨大的挑战。美国西蒙-舒斯特（Simon & Schuster)出版社新近出版的一本书专门探讨了美中经济如何融为一体以及为什么美中经济一体化对世界繁荣至关重要等问题。 这本书的题目是《超级融合：美中经济如何融为一体，为什么世界繁荣仰赖于它》(Superfusion: How China and America Became One Economy and Why the World's Prosperity Depends on It)，作者是扎卡里·卡拉贝尔( Zachary Karabell)。 卡拉贝尔认为，过去十多年来，中国经济和美国经济实际上已经变成了一个紧密交织的综合体系。两国如何打理这个体系将决定今后几十年全球会变得更加繁荣还是更加动荡。

巴黎 奥朗德周二（5月15日）宣誓就任总统 。在爱丽舍宫的权力交接仪式结束后，这位现年57岁的社会党人将宣布新总理人选。之后他将动身前往柏林访问。周二晚上，德国总理默克尔将为奥朗德举行隆重的欢迎仪式。欧元区危机将是双方领导人会晤的主要议题。奥朗德在竞选总统时就要求为严格的财政公约增加促进经济增长的条款。德国总理默克尔对此原则上表示同意。但是她不希望实施昂贵的经济刺激计划。 雅典 希腊总统帕普利亚斯提议成立一个专家政府以解决国家危机。按照总统的设想，专家政府应该尽可能多地获得议会中各政党的支持。

戛纳电影节第二重要的奖项是评审团大奖，今年获此殊荣的是法国影片《每分钟120击》（120 Battements par minute），导演是佳姆皮罗（Robin Campillo）。佳姆皮罗生于摩洛哥，本来是一名剧作家以及电影剪辑，《每分钟120击》是他的处女作，讲述了上世纪90年代末艾滋病蔓延的故事。该片一经放映便获得热评。克鲁格是在好莱坞发展的德国演员，今年度的戛纳电影节上被评为最佳女演员，是对其在阿金（Fatih Akins）执导的《从天而降》（Aus dem Nichts）里扮演女主角的表彰。这也是戛纳电影节自1986年以来德国演员再度获奖。

“新冠疫苗；中国外交的新武器”，这是该报多名记者联合撰写的文章的标题。 该报记者注意到， 中国研发的疫苗正陆续运往一些国家.但这一次中国官方媒体显得十分低调，没有像年初的口罩外交那样高调渲染。这并不意味着没有疫苗外交。文章分析了这种谨慎的三大可能的理由。一是中国现代国际关系学院今年4月的一份报告承认，中国围绕口罩外交的宣传适得其反， 自1989年的天安门事件以后，中国的国际形象从未如此糟糕 。二是中国国内仍然不断有新增病例，优先将疫苗出口国外有可能令本国民众不满。三是中国体制不透明，公卫丑闻不断，缺乏信誉，中国因此希望谨慎前行。

1970 年和 1986 年举办过世界杯的墨西哥市奥林匹克体育场。照片来自 Flickr 用户djmfuentes (CC BY-NC 2.0)。部落格 El Universal 带我们看到民众如何在 1986 世界杯开幕式上炮轰当时的总统 Miguel de la Madrid。总统演讲中超过九万名观众愤怒叫嚣着，因为政府决定在距离 1985 年九月十九日墨西哥市大地震仅仅八个月后就主办世界杯赛事。1982 年当国际足总决定哥伦比亚不符主办资格后，墨西哥接过了主办 1986 世界杯这个担子。当时墨西哥室内五人制足球联盟的主席 Rafael Castillo 表示墨西哥只需要一桶油漆和一把刷子就够了，因为国内的当时的硬件规格只有十六年历史（为 1970 年世界杯所建造的）。国际足总在 1956 年举行高峰会以决定 1962 年世界杯的主办国。智利的体育主管 Carlos Dittborn 以精彩的演说为他的国家赢得了这项荣耀，他说：「我们什么都没有，所以我们希望做到一切。」

丽思卡尔顿酒店的监视摄像机显示，涉嫌制造自杀式炸弹袭击者在爆炸前不久携带一个带轮子的小手提箱直接进入餐厅隔壁的一个房间里 。国际公司的一些高级代表经常在这个房间举行定期会晤。 据报纸报道，酒店的一名员工曾上前询问这位不速之客来这里做什么。他回答是给他的老板来送参加会议所需要的文件。其中一名会议参加者是前澳大利亚和印尼经济联合会主席诺克·基罗扬 。他接受澳大利亚电台采访时说： "大多数人来得有些迟，因此都坐在靠近门口的地方。我坐在另一端的一张桌子旁，距离爆炸的地方最远。我们的桌子坐着四个人，都幸免于难。

2011年中国国民心灵之殇，排头名的应属 “7.23”甬温线高铁特别重大交通事故。刚出版的《财经》杂志2011年第29期，发表长文《调查“动车调查”》。文中披露：动车事故的书面调查报告9月已经完成并递交给国务院。按国务院493号令—《生产安全事故报告和调查处理条例》：“特别重大事故的调查报告，应当自事故发生之日起最长不超过120日提交。负责调查的人民政府应当自收到事故调查报告之日起30日内做出批复，特殊情况下可以延长，但延长时间最长不超过30日。”如按9月底已经递交动车事故调查报告，最迟至11月30日，国务院或其授权的有关部门就应批复，作出处理，并向社会公布。

印度总理辛格1月13日抵达北京对中国进行为期三天的访问。这是印度总理在最近的五年里第一次访问中国。分析人士认为，随着两个人口大国经济的迅速发展，中印两国势必要在各个领域加强交流与合作。 *出任总理以来首次访华* 印度总理辛格的这次访华，是辛格自2004年出任总理以来的首次访华，也是印度总理在最近五年里对中国进行的首次访问。按照访问计划，辛格将会晤中国国家主席胡锦涛、人大常委会委员长吴邦国和国务院总理温家宝，讨论联合国的改革、全球气候变化、能源安全、国际贸易及民用核领域合作等问题。 最近几年，中印双方高层领导人之间的交流显著加强。中国总理温家宝2005年访问印度，双方宣布建立旨在实现和平和繁荣的战略合作夥伴关系。
